issue.title: macOS Illegal instruction: 4 (seen on Travis)
issue.body:
From [https://travis-ci.org/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/jobs/251993063](https://travis-ci.org/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/jobs/251993063), before the fails due to clang-format, we get the following error:

```
./test_kex
================================================================================
Sample computation for key exchange method LWE Frodo recommended
================================================================================
make: *** [test] Illegal instruction: 4
```

I have no idea where it comes from, I never got it on my mac. Anyone? Maybe we should `valgrind`.

comment.body: Fixed it by replacing .global in all asm files with .globl (that's because macOS uses some ancient "as" tool)

issue.title: Fix unknown pseudo-op: .global under macOS
issue.body:
replaced .global with .globl in all .S files due to ancient “as” tool
in macOS

issue.title: Fix windows build july2017
issue.body:
* Repaired Windows builds broken in the last few commits
  - Re-disabled NTRU by default on Windows; needs manual steps
  - Re-enabled SIDH by including malloc.h
* Enabled Kyber
* Updated project to VS2017

comment.body: @christianpaquin, macOS doesn't have <malloc.h> and according to this link (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12973311/difference-between-stdlib-h-and-malloc-h#12973361) the preferred approach is to use <stdlib.h>.  Can you check if that is okay on Windows?

issue.title: Fix unknown pseudo-op: .global under macOS
issue.body:
replaced .global with .globl in all .S files due to ancient “as” tool
in macOS

comment.body: @dstebila That's something odd going on, all test seem to pass, however Travis Build #498.5 spits out an Illegal Instruction on line 1789. It seems that `./test_rand --quiet` is spitting out this. I compiled and checked on my side (osX clang), everything works fine

issue.title: Fix windows build july2017
issue.body:
* Repaired Windows builds broken in the last few commits
  - Re-disabled NTRU by default on Windows; needs manual steps
  - Re-enabled SIDH by including malloc.h
* Enabled Kyber
* Updated project to VS2017

issue.title: Fix unknown pseudo-op: .global under macOS
issue.body:
replaced .global with .globl in all .S files due to ancient “as” tool
in macOS

comment.body:
Very weird.  Not sure why that makes a difference.

Google didn't help me much, the only partial explanation I could find was here, but it doesn't seem to offer a clear solution: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14268887/what-is-the-illegal-instruction-4-error-and-why-does-mmacosx-version-min-10

I've submitted a new PR #154 which switches the Xcode version to the same one on my desktop.  If that works, that seems like a bit of a cheat, but I don't really know how else to diagnose since we don't have old versions of macOS sitting around.

issue.title: Fix illegal instruction on macOS, redux

comment.body: This is still failing with a different version of macOS and a different version of Xcode.  I have no idea why and am not able to reproduce.  Any thoughts?

issue.title: Fix illegal instruction on macOS, redux

comment.body: @dstebila No idea! I cannot reproduce it at all, I have 3 versions of clang on my mac and all are running it fine. Can you perhaps add some of the params to "env" so we can see when it doesn't break anymore on Travis?

issue.title: Fix illegal instruction on macOS, redux

comment.body:
It looks like it might be the AES NI implementation causing problems.  Commit b273093 had AES_NI=0 in the first macOS build, which had previously been failing but didn't in that commit.  

So I propose we use AES_NI=0 for both our macOS builds for now -- that's commit caede46.  This would mean our test coverage on Travis doesn't cover the case of how must users will probably build on macOS.  But for Vlad and I it builds on our Macs with AES_NI=1.  And we probably won't be changing AES code much, so it seems like this small gap in test coverage is not likely to be too problematic.
